text: CompetitionObjectives By the end of this lecture, you should understand: • ‘Competition’ as a form of species interaction • Definitions of ‘intraspecific’ and ‘interspecific competition’ • Experimental methods used to determine the effects of competition • An understanding of some of the mechanisms species use to reduce levels of interspecific competition Species may interact in a Interspecific competition in plants “The principle that two species are more different where they occur together than when they are separated geographically.” Character displacement Controversial Ecology Mud snail feeding Character displacement www.geo.arizona.edu Niche Partitioning Avoiding competition “The influence of plants upon each other, caused by products of metabolism.” Allelopathy Controversial Ecology Greenhouse experiment to demonstrate the detrimental effects of grass on apple tree seedlings Allelopathy • Most widely distributed vascular plant in the world • One of the most ancient plants on Earth • Covers over 370,000 hectares in UK • Detrimental to agriculture, but some argue beneficial to biodiversity • Eaten by some human cultures but carcinogenic Allelopathy - bracken Pteridium aquilinum Produces phytotoxins that accumulate in the soil and kill germinating seeds Allelopathy - bracken • Introduced in mid-1700s as garden shrub • Allelopathic and highly invasive, very difficult to control • Favours acidic soils of Wales & Scotland Rhododendron ponticumSummary • ‘Intraspecific competition: competition between individuals of same species • Interspecific competition: competition between individuals of different species • Manipulating species density and relative abundance allows detailed study of interspecific interactions • Similar species may reduce interspecific competition by: 1. ‘Character displacement’ 2. ‘Niche partitioning’ • Some plants reduce local competition by ‘allelopathy’ References and acknowledgements: • Kruuk, H.
